content:
This post is based on the chapter Artificial Intelligence, Automation, and Work [[1]] by Daron Acemoglu and Pascual Restrepo, from the Handbook The Economics of Artificial Intelligence. It also draws on related research by Acemoglu, Restrepo, and coauthors [[References]]. These works offer a framework for analyzing how automation affects labor markets using a task-based approach.
Channels of Automation’s Impact on labor demand There are several key mechanisms through which automation influences labor demand, wages, and labor’s share in the economy. Importantly, the displacement effect stands out as the main negative force, while other mechanisms counterbalance it to varying degrees.
The Displacement Effect: The Negative Impact Displacement effect: Automation makes capital more productive and leads to the substitution of labor with capital. As a result, labor demand and equilibrium wages tend to decline, reducing employment and labor’s share of national income. This is the primary …
title: Automation, AI, and the Future of Work: Insights from Economics

content: Instrumental Variable approach for Casual Inference If we believe that a variable XXX causes (or affects) another variable YYY, we are often interested in studying how much the value of YYY changes if we make a small δx\delta xδx change in XXX. For example, how much do people dislike traffic on their street can be measured by decrease in house prices in response to increase in street traffic. The statistical technique most commonly used to answer causal questions is the linear regression [1]Y=βX+Cγ+ϵ Y = \beta X + C\gamma + \epsilon Y=βX+Cγ+ϵ where CCC is the matrix of control variables and we assume that standard OLS assumption holds. However, even when XXX and YYY are causally related, the estimate of β\betaβ is unbiased only if XXX and ϵ\epsilonϵ are independent conditioned on CCC. This is often not the case in practice. In our example, he construction of a new housing development in a neighborhood may increase traffic prices while lowering the house prices, but this decrease in …
title: IV method and its application to traffic's impact on house prices

This post is based on the chapter Artificial Intelligence, Automation, and Work [[1]] by Daron Acemoglu and Pascual Restrepo, from the Handbook The Economics of Artificial Intelligence. It also draws on related research by Acemoglu, Restrepo, and coauthors [[References]]. These works offer a framework for analyzing how automation affects labor markets using a task-based approach.
Channels of Automation’s Impact on labor demand There are several key mechanisms through which automation influences labor demand, wages, and labor’s share in the economy. Importantly, the displacement effect stands out as the main negative force, while other mechanisms counterbalance it to varying degrees.
The Displacement Effect: The Negative Impact Displacement effect: Automation makes capital more productive and leads to the substitution of labor with capital. As a result, labor demand and equilibrium wages tend to decline, reducing employment and labor’s share of national income. This is the primary …
title: Automation, AI, and the Future of Work: Insights from Economics

content: Instrumental Variable approach for Casual Inference If we believe that a variable XXX causes (or affects) another variable YYY, we are often interested in studying how much the value of YYY changes if we make a small δx\delta xδx change in XXX. For example, how much do people dislike traffic on their street can be measured by decrease in house prices in response to increase in street traffic. The statistical technique most commonly used to answer causal questions is the linear regression [1]Y=βX+Cγ+ϵ Y = \beta X + C\gamma + \epsilon Y=βX+Cγ+ϵ where CCC is the matrix of control variables and we assume that standard OLS assumption holds. However, even when XXX and YYY are causally related, the estimate of β\betaβ is unbiased only if XXX and ϵ\epsilonϵ are independent conditioned on CCC. This is often not the case in practice. In our example, he construction of a new housing development in a neighborhood may increase traffic prices while lowering the house prices, but this decrease in …
title: IV method and its application to traffic's impact on house prices

This post is based on the chapter Artificial Intelligence, Automation, and Work [[1]] by Daron Acemoglu and Pascual Restrepo, from the Handbook The Economics of Artificial Intelligence. It also draws on related research by Acemoglu, Restrepo, and coauthors [[References]]. These works offer a framework for analyzing how automation affects labor markets using a task-based approach.
Channels of Automation’s Impact on labor demand There are several key mechanisms through which automation influences labor demand, wages, and labor’s share in the economy. Importantly, the displacement effect stands out as the main negative force, while other mechanisms counterbalance it to varying degrees.
The Displacement Effect: The Negative Impact Displacement effect: Automation makes capital more productive and leads to the substitution of labor with capital. As a result, labor demand and equilibrium wages tend to decline, reducing employment and labor’s share of national income. This is the primary …
title: Automation, AI, and the Future of Work: Insights from Economics

content: Instrumental Variable approach for Casual Inference If we believe that a variable XXX causes (or affects) another variable YYY, we are often interested in studying how much the value of YYY changes if we make a small δx\delta xδx change in XXX. For example, how much do people dislike traffic on their street can be measured by decrease in house prices in response to increase in street traffic. The statistical technique most commonly used to answer causal questions is the linear regression [1]Y=βX+Cγ+ϵ Y = \beta X + C\gamma + \epsilon Y=βX+Cγ+ϵ where CCC is the matrix of control variables and we assume that standard OLS assumption holds. However, even when XXX and YYY are causally related, the estimate of β\betaβ is unbiased only if XXX and ϵ\epsilonϵ are independent conditioned on CCC. This is often not the case in practice. In our example, he construction of a new housing development in a neighborhood may increase traffic prices while lowering the house prices, but this decrease in …
title: IV method and its application to traffic's impact on house prices

This post is based on the chapter Artificial Intelligence, Automation, and Work [[1]] by Daron Acemoglu and Pascual Restrepo, from the Handbook The Economics of Artificial Intelligence. It also draws on related research by Acemoglu, Restrepo, and coauthors [[References]]. These works offer a framework for analyzing how automation affects labor markets using a task-based approach.
Channels of Automation’s Impact on labor demand There are several key mechanisms through which automation influences labor demand, wages, and labor’s share in the economy. Importantly, the displacement effect stands out as the main negative force, while other mechanisms counterbalance it to varying degrees.
The Displacement Effect: The Negative Impact Displacement effect: Automation makes capital more productive and leads to the substitution of labor with capital. As a result, labor demand and equilibrium wages tend to decline, reducing employment and labor’s share of national income. This is the primary …
html: A comprehensive economic analysis of how AI and automation affect labor markets, featuring a task-based framework by Acemoglu and Restrepo.
title: Automation, AI, and the Future of Work: Insights from Economics

content: Instrumental Variable approach for Casual Inference If we believe that a variable XXX causes (or affects) another variable YYY, we are often interested in studying how much the value of YYY changes if we make a small δx\delta xδx change in XXX. For example, how much do people dislike traffic on their street can be measured by decrease in house prices in response to increase in street traffic. The statistical technique most commonly used to answer causal questions is the linear regression [1]Y=βX+Cγ+ϵ Y = \beta X + C\gamma + \epsilon Y=βX+Cγ+ϵ where CCC is the matrix of control variables and we assume that standard OLS assumption holds. However, even when XXX and YYY are causally related, the estimate of β\betaβ is unbiased only if XXX and ϵ\epsilonϵ are independent conditioned on CCC. This is often not the case in practice. In our example, he construction of a new housing development in a neighborhood may increase traffic prices while lowering the house prices, but this decrease in …
title: IV method and its application to traffic's impact on house prices

content:
Introduction As artificial intelligence and robotics accelerate technological change, a critical question emerges: What does automation mean for workers and wage inequality? This post explores this question through the lens of modern economic theory, drawing on groundbreaking research by Daron Acemoglu and Pascual Restrepo.
While automation has historically led to job creation and rising living standards, recent developments raise concerns about whether this pattern will persist. Using a task-based framework, we can decompose automation&rsquo;s effects into distinct channels: some harmful to workers (displacement), others beneficial (productivity and task creation). Understanding these mechanisms is essential for policymakers and workers alike as we navigate the AI revolution.
This post synthesizes insights from the chapter Artificial Intelligence, Automation, and Work by Daron Acemoglu and Pascual Restrepo from The Economics of Artificial Intelligence handbook, providing both …
html: A comprehensive economic analysis of how AI and automation affect labor markets, featuring a task-based framework by Acemoglu and Restrepo.
